newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - Dollar weaker on uncertainty over Japan.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Dollar weaker on uncertainty over Japan.

text.p: The dollar opened European trading on Monday almost a pfennig weaker than Friday's levels with investors jittery over Tokyo's monetary policy ahead of a key Japanese economic survey due this week.

The U.S. currency had slipped to 1.4777 marks by mid-morning compared with Friday's European close of 1.4871 in dealings that were subdued as British markets were closed because of a seasonal holiday.
Equity markets in Frankfurt and Paris were mixed but again business was quiet because of London's closure.
On the foreign exchanges, the dollar, which began sliding from 1.49 levels last week as euphoria over a German interest rate cut fizzled out, fell further because of growing uncertainty over Japan.
The Bank of Japan's quarterly Tankan survey on companies' expectations of future business is out on Wednesday and is regarded as an important reference for formulating monetary policy.
Although few expect the survey to change Japan's steady monetary policy stance markets become nervous because the lower the Tankan's index, the gloomier the outlook.
The dollar also fell to 107. 89 yen, compared to 108.50 in late European trading on Friday.
The mark was stronger against European currencies as well, gaining against the French franc and posted hefty gains on the lira.
Mark/lira was trading at 1022.90 from 1018.82 on Friday. Mark/French franc was at 3.4181 against 3.4137.
Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said in La Repubblica newspaper that Italy did not want a revision of the Maastricht criteria.
Prodi's comments come after a weekend newspaper interview by his deputy, Walter Veltroni, who said that Italy and other European countries should consider the possibility of a Maastricht re-think.
In Frankfurt, stocks were down with sentiment hit by lower German bonds, the weaker dollar and a negative close on Wall Street on Friday.
In early bourse trade the DAX index, which measures floor trade in 30 blue-chip German shares, was down 5.35 points at 2,549.81.

"There is very little going on here today and volumes seem very thin. Also London is closed because of the bank holiday," said a Frankfurt dealer, adding that interest should pick up after the holiday season ends around next week.

French stocks too were weaker at the open, weighed down by the fragile franc, but picked up slightly later. The CAC-40 index was just in positive territory by mid-morning in trading kept thin by London's holiday.
Last Thursday and Friday, the bourse rose after the Bank of France cut its intervention rate to 3.35 percent following a surprise Bundesbank repo rate cut.
But dealers said the rate cuts would have a limited effect on the French economy and therefore its longer term boost to the CAC-40 was doubtful.
"While the rate cut is positive, it wasn't big enough to completely change the economic situation, which is quasi-recessionist when you look at price indices and consumer confidence," said a trader.
CURRENCIES AT 1030 GMT
The dollar was at 1.4777 marks and 107.89 yen compared with 1.4871 marks and 108.50 yen at the London close on Friday.
STOCK MARKETS AT 1030 GMT
The London stock market is closed for a public holiday. On Friday the FTSE 100 closed at 3,907.5 up 16.4 points.
In Paris, the CAC-40 share index was up 0.56 points to 2,021.38.
The 30-share DAX index in Frankfurt was down 5.35 points at 2,549.81.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold was stronger at $388.45 versus $387.50 at Friday's London close. Activity was expected to be quiet with London markets closed for a public holiday. Silver was unchanged at $5.24.
